When i look at the card, the word that comes in my mind is "dependeble".

Fall - if cast on turn 3, i guess there's like 75% chance to discard 2 cards. Even on turn 2, if you didn't begin and opponent has 2 lands in play, theres high likelihood of 1-for-2 trade.

Later, when opponent is topdecking, you can Rasie dead some of your dead buddies and bounce one of theirs.
For example, you could return Ravenous Rats and discard their creature...which is kind of complicated way of destroying a creature, but it's a way (plus its something Mind Rot or Blightning cant do).

In either case, it's quite color heavy. Thats why i rate just 4.

107423: Rise // Fall.author: Mode
107423: Rise // Fall.text_parsed:
Both parts of this split card are pretty playable.

Fall is alright, but it's that it won't have much impact while your opponent still has any land cards in hand, but it can still manage to become a Hymn to Tourach if you're lucky.

Rise is really decent. This combines Unsummon and Disentomb in one card, which means card advantage. Both cards are playable by themselves, and this will most often find its targets to resolve. The obvious disadvatage is that you can't use it as an Unsummon as response to removal, as a combat trick or similar.

Yet if you have this split card twice in your hand, both parts synergize with each other - bounce your opponent's creature with Rise. then make him discard it with Fall. Effectively makes a Terminate (albeit with card disadvantage) that can also get rid of indestructible creature and creatures with persist. Rise and Fall, my dear :D
It gets even better if your opponent kept a single card in hand that will also get discarded in the process. Especially if you have something like Liliana's Caress out. In which case you might even want to return a creature from your opponent's graveyard to his hand in case he doesn't have any cards in hand at that time.

@desolation_masticore: Something tells me that combining pump effects like Reckless Charge and Giant Growth in one card would be severely overpowered - even without flashback. I haven't seen a burn spell for that combines two Lightning Bolts for 6 damage yet ;)

107423: Rise // Fall.author: Alsebra
107423: Rise // Fall.text_parsed: @MisterAction - You can try to bait your blue opponent into wasting a counter on a non-essential card, but many blue mages know which spells to counter...or they're packing a few more.
107423: Rise // Fall.text_posted: @MisterAction - You can try to bait your blue opponent into wasting a counter on a non-essential card, but many blue mages know which spells to counter...or they're packing a few more.

107423: Rise // Fall.author: MisterAction
107423: Rise // Fall.text_parsed:
Yeah... I appreciate them trying to fix a classic spell, but they should just leave Hymn to Tourach alone. It's still effortless card advantage for two mana, and random discard is an incredibly frustrating mechanic that should be abandoned. At least Counterspell can be defeated by waiting until your opponent is tapped out or playing less-essential spells as decoys to trick them into wasting their counters. That feels more like strategy to me and less like luck.

Rise is great, though! I've played this card in decks that don't even have red, and it does fine.

@Alsebra: That's what I'm saying, countermagic is an acceptable mechanic in my eyes because it requires proper timing and planning to use correctly. Countermagic can be beaten by outthinking your opponent; random discard can only be defeated by luck. Or... countermagic.

Great card and really hard to get rid of since it can prevent most removal from your opponent, including Krosan Grip for instance.
Anything a player will be able to cast once this card hits the table are creatures, what makes watching your opponent easier most of the time.
Scattershot Archer for instance can keep the heaven clean in case you mainly run other creature cards which don't mind this.

It's also fun when you cast noncreature spells that can't be countered, since it will both resolve and provide an accordant amount of bird.

107428: Dovescape.author: Pwnsaw
107428: Dovescape.text_parsed:
Dovescape + Guile + noncreature spell (played by anyone) = infinite doves

1) Spell is cast
2) Dovescape triggers, tokens are made
3) Guile exiles the spell, the you choose to cast the spell
4) Repeat steps 1-3 until infinite is achieved, then choose not to cast the exiled spell.

Turn 7 combo seems kinda slow though, but still very satisfying and relatively easy to fit into a deck.

107428: Dovescape.author: CallmeMerry
107428: Dovescape.text_parsed:
Umm...instead of trying to wipe the board, just use Mycosynth Lattice + Blinkmoth Infusion to throw down lots of birds, or just use Heroes Remembered. Both of those are in color and can net you 9 or 14 birds. Affinity knocks down blinkmoth's casting cost substantially, so you can cast for cheap and suspend Heroes Remembered early (with Clockspinning / Dust of Moments to accel) and have plenty of field presence. Several people already already mentioned Boseji so you can hardcast them late-game for the spell and the birds.

Chronomantic Escape and Reality Strobe can be used early game to keep you alive (especially with Paradox Haze) and net you 6 more birds once this hits the board. Same goes for Dichotomancy. Either hardcast with Boseji and copy their board (since you aren't playing those cards, they won't be countered). Enough said, my favorite victory is just throwing down a Deepchannel Mentor and just attacking for the win.

107428: Dovescape.author: Ferlord
107428: Dovescape.text_parsed:
Grand Arbiter does a good job when this is around (Just a coincidence that they're both Azorius? Sure thing, pal). I mean, at least in EDH.

One way or another, you'll usually be on top: if they cast a 4-cost spell (like No Mercy), it'll cost 5. If you cast a 4-cost W/U spell (like Cloud Cover), it'll cost 2. For , you get 4 1/1 flyers, and they get the same for . Win win, right?

Not only that, but this can't be destroyed other than by a Indrik Stomphowler or something similar.
Boardwipes aren't going to be an issue either, unless you're suffering (they gave you a Steel Golem? uh oh...)

In general, a card you have to play sparingly. Reminds me of Infernal Genesis.

107431: Valor Made Real.author: humor_love
107431: Valor Made Real.text_parsed:
@ spirit_of_blue:

Jareth's block-boost happens one time when blocking - not once per attacker blocked. However, Meglonoth's ability to deal its power in damage to controllers of blocked creatures DOES occur for each attacker blocked. Meglonoth's blocking ability is better served with something like Valor Made Real, which can be game-winning if the attacking player attacks with any kind of numbers.

@ Mode and everybody else:

This card is not Blaze of Glory with a slight buff. This card allows one creature (you'll usually target a creature you control) to block any number of creatures. Blaze of Glory FORCES an opponent's creature to block all attackers. Similar - and even comparable - but different, nevertheless.
107431: Valor Made Real.text_posted:
@ spirit_of_blue:

Jareth's block-boost happens one time when blocking - not once per attacker blocked. However, Meglonoth's ability to deal its power in damage to controllers of blocked creatures DOES occur for each attacker blocked. Meglonoth's blocking ability is better served with something like Valor Made Real, which can be game-winning if the attacking player attacks with any kind of numbers.

@ Mode and everybody else:

This card is not Blaze of Glory with a slight buff. This card allows one creature (you'll usually target a creature you control) to block any number of creatures. Blaze of Glory FORCES an opponent's creature to block all attackers. Similar - and even comparable - but different, nevertheless.

107435: Delirium Skeins.author: SAUS3
107435: Delirium Skeins.text_parsed:
@blindthrall
This card is better once you ARE hellbent, but last rites would be better for GETTING hellbent. You can discard any number of cards (so you can get hellbent no matter what), and instead of your opponent keeping their best cards, they keep their worst cards (assuming they have any left).

This card is a staple in zombie horde decks because it massively disrupts the players. So devastating when you've played your first 3 turns, and you're down to around 4 cards in hand, and then this is the first card off the top.

107435: Delirium Skeins.author: RAV0004
107435: Delirium Skeins.text_parsed:
This is the only card in magic that does what it does. A few thoughts, since I've built a craploads of decks around using this card:

IT NAILS EVERY SINGLE OPPONENT
IT DISCARDS THREE CARDS
IT EMPTIES YOUR HAND (EVERY TIME)

One With Nothing is a potent effect for the decks that need it, although it's not worth it at sorcery speed (Putrid Imps is better). Delirium Skeins is a One With Nothing with card advantage built in. Rather than being a one-of combo piece, it's become MASSIVE hand disruption. The distance between two and three is so great in magic that you really have no idea until you've played a deck built around this card. At the very absolute least, you're going to empty half of your opponent's hand. At the most, you simply floor it into nothing.

107435: Delirium Skeins.author: TheShadow344
107435: Delirium Skeins.text_parsed:
I've been playing a lot of 3-player matches recently and found that my discard deck just didn't have enough disruption. Sure, Hymn to Tourach is great, but it only hits one player at a time - you run out of gas too fast with this method of attack.

No more! I burn through my hand fast enough that discarding whatever cards remain in my hand is worth making my opponents discard a good chunk of theirs. Puts them that much closer to being in Quest for the Nihil Stone / Shrieking Affliction / The Rack range.

I'm a sucker for symmetrical effects like this. Also sick with Geth's Grimoire.

107438: Rakdos the Defiler.author: person1234
107438: Rakdos the Defiler.text_parsed: Actually ToidiDiPuts you'd only sacrifice 3/4ths of your non-Demon permanents if you attacked with 2 of these with Mirror Gallery in play. Each trigger would go on the stack independently and resolve one at a time. The first one takes out 1/2 of your non-demon permanents and the 2nd one takes out half of the ones that are left over so you could theoretically have enough permanents to keep mirror gallery in play so they wouldn't die to the legends rule. Or you could also March of the Machines + Conspiracy to ensure you never have to sac the Gallery to Rakdos.

107438: Rakdos the Defiler.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
107438: Rakdos the Defiler.text_parsed:
I was so excited to get a copy of the leader of the Rakdos guild! Like most demons, he offers you mana-efficient power in return for sacrifice. Rakdos' sacrifice, though, is steeper than most, to make up for his extremely strong combat damage trigger. As many people here have pointed out, you would really hesitate to use him for fear of attacking, sacrificing dutifully and then having him "swordsed" before he deals any damage to your opponent.

If you ever had a way to get Rakdos into play "tapped and attacking" (a la ninjutsu), though... he would be a force to be reckoned with. Volrath's Shapeshifter comes to mind. I'm sure there must be other tricks...

107438: Rakdos the Defiler.author: Japicx
107438: Rakdos the Defiler.text_parsed:
@Demonic Math Tutor

Rakdos would probably make a better EDH general, if only because there's no fun in playing against a Kaervek deck. Using Kaervek suggests that you don't care about fun or good deck construction; it just makes you look like a jerk.
As for Rakdos, he's scary, but he can backfire rather easily. In EDH, where Swords to Plowshares and Trickbind are staples, Rakdos can easily end up hurting you a lot more than an opponent. He also becomes markedly less threatening in multiplayer games.
If you're looking for a black-red general, Malfegor is probably a better choice. He quickly sweeps your opponents' board (something that very few generals can do) and your deck will be built to make having cards in your graveyard a positive.
I know I didn't really answer your "Which is better?" question, but Malfegor is an option you should consider.

107438: Rakdos the Defiler.author: Subbak
107438: Rakdos the Defiler.text_parsed:
@Nagrus: In Magic, "attacks" mean exactly one thing: "be declared as an attacker in the Decalre Attackers step". With Kaalia, Rakdos is never declared as an attacker but rather enters the battlefield attacking, so this ability does not trigger.

107438: Rakdos the Defiler.author: ParallaxtheRevan
107438: Rakdos the Defiler.text_parsed:
Oni Possession is a must for all the Kaalia fans out there looking at this card.

With enough Black and White, and multi-Black/Red cards in your deck (remember- death triggers! :), you really don't need to be all that sad about your Angels and Dragons dying (I wouldn't go with All Demons, some cards are just too good to pass up- particularly Baneslayer Angel and Akroma) because you'll be able to Reanimate them out with some kind of Living Death effect anyway-

HOWEVER. You really don't want to be caught sacrificing Kaalia herself. Thanks to Aurelia, the Warbringer you might find yourself in the midgame actually not minding at all the idea of sacrificing Sol Ring or your Signets, because your cards are just a little stupid good together. :3 But Kaalia of the Vast is a non-Demon permanent, and a forced sacrifice is something no Lightning Greaves or Sword of War and Peace can save her from.

Oni Possession might seem like a steep investment to make Rakdos the Defiler able to shine as much as he needs to, but you'll have enough Tutors and if you really really want to fetch Rakdos as your first beatstick every game, white has some cards specifically good for enchantments and auras to smoothly get Oni Possession when and where you need it.

Some of my favorites, after going through Gatherer first by Community Rating, then by taste. There's over 100 Dragons, and about that many Angels and Demons too. shortening all of them down to a list of less than 30 is tough- here's a good set though:

White: White-Red/White-Black:
Avacyn, Angel of Hope Aurelia the Warbringer
Baneslayer Angel Gisela, Blade of Goldnight
Angel of Serenity Angel of Despair
Yosei, the Morning Star

Black: Black-Red:
Reiver Demon Malfegor
Stronghold Overseer Rakdos the Defiler
Bloodgift Demon Vampiric Dragon
Rune-Scarred Demon Bladewing the Risen
Kokusho, the Evening Star

Red: White-Black-Red:
Thundermaw Hellkite Oros, the Avenger
Bogardan Hellkite

107440: Soulsworn Jury.author: ELeeLo

If this guy activated his counter and i disperse him In response !!,....

WHAT HAPPEN ???

Thank you :D
107440: Soulsworn Jury.text_posted:
If this guy activated his counter and i disperse him In response !!,....

WHAT HAPPEN ???

Thank you :D

107440: Soulsworn Jury.author: Ataraxiom
107440: Soulsworn Jury.text_parsed:
ELeeLo, if you activated the counter ability on Soulsworn Jury, the following would happen:


- You would pay 1U and sacrifice the Soulsworn Jury, targeting a creature spell on the stack.

- You would cast Disperse, but would be unable to target the Jury because it would already have been sacrificed.

- You would be forced to choose a legal target for Disperse, or not cast it at all.


This happens because sacrificing the Soulsworn Jury is a cost, not an effect. Therefore, the cost is paid immediately and cannot be responded to or interrupted in a normal way. The downside to this is that you cannot use spells like Disperse to save your Jury for reuse later. The upside is that your opponent cannot use a killspell like Murder on your Jury in response to you activating its ability, because it has already left the battlefield and therefore cannot be targeted.

All costs for an ability are shown to the left of the colon. All effects are shown to the right of the colon.

This happens because sacrificing the Soulsworn Jury is a cost, not an effect. Therefore, the cost is paid immediately and cannot be responded to or interrupted in a normal way. 107445: Odds // Ends.author: Kelrath
107445: Odds // Ends.text_parsed:
@Tezz: No, If a card has any mana symbols on it that aren't any of the commander's colors, then it can't be included in your EDH deck.

For the consideration of split cards in EDH, each card in a split card contributes its colors to the split card's colors as a whole.
107445: Odds // Ends.text_posted:

107445: Odds // Ends.author: gman92
107445: Odds // Ends.text_parsed:
@leomistico: People who say "USA!" at all the RWU cards are just being patriotic, not narrow-minded. They're showing respect and deference for their own great country, not narrow mindedness and contempt for all others. There is nothing wrong with that.

On a better note: Odds and Ends is one of my favorites, if not my favorite, split card. Imprint on Isochron Scepter for some fun. Both of its effects are really nice though, unlike a lot of split cards that favor one side more than the other. The idea of a coin toss coming up in your favor either way in Magic is nearly unheard of, so Odds really does it for me.

4.5/5

107445: Odds // Ends.author: leomistico
107445: Odds // Ends.text_parsed:
One day there was this play:

My opponent: Cast Dimir Cutpurse
I: draw-go (I had this and a creature in hand, but I refuse to playt it since I knew what my opponent had in his library)
My opponent: Cast Hellhole Rats, I discarded a land. My opponent attacks with both creature, I cast Ends! Such satisfaction!

Both half has its uses, I like Odds more, since I love Izzet, but Ends is very useful nontheless! The win-win is a great idea, even if doesn't happen alway (against a Day of Judgment wouldn't work), but agains counter it does! I played it in a deck, that used almost only multi-colored cards, and had some Pillar of the Paruns for fixing, so I could play the End part without others mana fixing, even if not always, but pretty often.

5/5

Also, stop b*tching about U.S.A. in every card. As someone else said in a comment from another card, blue-white-red represents so many flags of the world (France, just for an example), that always thinking about U.S.A. reveals your totally blindness for what doesn't concern your country... Yours' not the best country in the world, so please, don't bother...

Edit:
@gman92: Oh, yeah... Because thinking about United States of America everytime they see blue-red-white colors make them so different from a Pavlov's dog...

107445: Odds // Ends.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
107445: Odds // Ends.text_parsed:
Did anyone notice FATTKIDD was being sarcastic? Steven Colbert is a satirical comedian who pokes fun at overly patriotic Americans... But to avoid hurt feelings, why don't we call that color combination "leomistico" instead, since his face turns white, then red, then blue when he hears the word America. (It's a Pavlovian conditioned reflex.)

OK, OK, OK, I should write about the card. Krark's Thumb will make your choice more likely, but the ruling specifically states there is no winning or losing the flip, so Chance Encounter will never get a luck counter.

I wish there were more cards like this that give an interesting good result for each outcome. Too many cards that use coins have a good or a bad outcome, or even worse, a good outcome or nothing. I play because I like to do stuff. I don't want to play a card that has a fifty percent chance of being boring!

The deck i run uses mostly one of a kind flyers so its easy to tutor them out. works especially well with Steel of the Godhead and Ocular Halo. Plus if you get Steel of the Godhead on Isperia you can just give him Magebane Armor until stormtide hits the field

107448: Isperia the Inscrutable.author: Tassarus
107448: Isperia the Inscrutable.text_parsed: i run twin copies of this beautiful lady in a U/W deck, classic Azorius playstyle around flying and tapping. the thing i Cannot Stress Enough is that, even on the first swing you call wrong, YOUR OPPONENET HAS TO REVEAL THEIR HAND. just remember what theyve got and watch what they play (having a photographic memory helps ftw). twin Sage Owls, and Telling Times help get what i need, twin Aven Mimeomancers (almost all the cards in it are in twin sets, as i've found it most effective; greatest still-reliable variety) plenty of tapping cards, Sleep, Fulgent Distraction, Plumes of Peace, and, to use that to its fullest, twin Palliation Accords and a searchable-with-Isperia Sunblast Angel. it may be flying- heavy, but i PREFER to play Against heavily-anti-flying decks for the Challenge of it and i STILL win. Isperia my dear, you are the epitome of versatility.

107449: Skyscribing.author: grundledib
107449: Skyscribing.text_parsed:
@SavageBrain: In draw-pain decks. This card looks as if it could be insanely effective combined with Underworld Dreams and Megrim-based decks. Could also be played with Words Of War to do silly amounts of damage.

It's players like you (that's not an insult, it's gratitude) that make draw-pain decks so effective - no one in their right mind would want to stop their opponent putting the spells they want into their hand, it's just stupid right? Well, yes, until you're taking 10+ damage per turn (no joke) for the privilege. This card may well sneak its way into my draw-pain deck...

107449: Skyscribing.author: Kurhan
107449: Skyscribing.text_parsed:
Combos:

Underworld Dreams - Opponent takes 1 damage per draw
Megrim - Opponents takes 2 damage per discard
Storm Seeker - Opponent takes 1 damage per card in hand
Sudden Impact - same as Storm Seeker
Multani, Maro-Sorcerer - creature who's power and toughness = number of cards in all players hands
Black Vise - deals damage to an opponent at the begining of their upkeep for each card over 4 in their hand
...and the list could go on for pages

Overall not a bad card, it just requires you to think a bit...which is hard for some people.

107451: Unliving Psychopath.author: CXA26483
107451: Unliving Psychopath.text_parsed:
Definitely an excellent zombie. Overcosted? At 2BB, you cast this guy as early as turn 3, with another pump card like Death Baron, Undead Warchief, and Cemetery Reaper, and just start blasting your opponents field for {B} per turn... In my zombie deck, anything you can't kill with this or Nameless Inversion, you force your opponent to sacrifice with Fleshbag Marauder and Call to the Grave.

At the very least, ~'s unusually high toughness for a zombie makes for a good blocker, which you can EOT destroy something on an opposing field. IMO, if you aren't playing this card, it's one of two things: Your playing a more aggro heavy build, or your doing it wrong.

107451: Unliving Psychopath.author: GrimjawxRULES
107451: Unliving Psychopath.text_parsed:
@CXA26483: You've got a very good point. In a Zombie deck, all those lords should be able to pump Unliving Psychopath to the extend that he can also take down larger threats easily. The relatively high toughness for a Zombie is also nice. At 4cc, you'd usually be casting something like Death Baron before him, leaving you with a handy 1/5 deathtouch blocker until you start using him offensively. Nameless Inversion can also pump him up in case you're in need of mana, so you might also be wise in running it in favor of Doom Blade and whatnot.

Also, another card that really makes this card good is Undead Warchief. It solves all the problems with high manacost and low power that one may have. As CXA26483 said; either you're playing too aggressively to include this guy, or you're doing it wrong.

107472: Aquastrand Spider.author: sarroth
107472: Aquastrand Spider.text_parsed:
I don't know if graft could be used with persist decks. Would the grafting of a +1/+1 counter actually remove the -1/-1 counter from a card with persist, or would there just be two counters on the card whose effects cancel each other? Because even if the counters cancel each other and the +1/+1 and -1/-1 make the card +0/+0 from whatever it is, if the -1/-1 counter is still on the card when it hits the graveyard the persist ability will not trigger.

I can say though that the graft ability, combined with Aquastrand Spider's other ability, is good to give green creatures reach that would not otherwise have it. Combine with Llanowar Reborn to graft more counters onto creatures.
107472: Aquastrand Spider.text_posted:
I don't know if graft could be used with persist decks. Would the grafting of a +1/+1 counter actually remove the -1/-1 counter from a card with persist, or would there just be two counters on the card whose effects cancel each other? Because even if the counters cancel each other and the +1/+1 and -1/-1 make the card +0/+0 from whatever it is, if the -1/-1 counter is still on the card when it hits the graveyard the persist ability will not trigger.

I can say though that the graft ability, combined with Aquastrand Spider's other ability, is good to give green creatures reach that would not otherwise have it. Combine with [autocard]Llanowar Reborn[/autocard] to graft more counters onto creatures.

107472: Aquastrand Spider.author: Ganryu
107472: Aquastrand Spider.text_parsed: sarroth: I think that as a state-based effect ANY counters that cancel eachother out will be removed. A creature with a +1/+1 counter and a -1/-1 counter on it will, as a state based effect, have both counters removed.
107472: Aquastrand Spider.text_posted: sarroth: I think that as a state-based effect ANY counters that cancel eachother out will be removed. A creature with a +1/+1 counter and a -1/-1 counter on it will, as a state based effect, have both counters removed.

107472: Aquastrand Spider.author: Andon_A
107472: Aquastrand Spider.text_parsed: That is indeed correct. If a creature has a +1/+1 counter on it, adding a -1/-1 counter removes it. That works the same the other way around as well. That's why persist can be such a PITA. Granted, this wasn't how it was originally, IIRC, but it is how it is now.
107472: Aquastrand Spider.text_posted: That is indeed correct. If a creature has a +1/+1 counter on it, adding a -1/-1 counter removes it. That works the same the other way around as well. That's why persist can be such a PITA. Granted, this wasn't how it was originally, IIRC, but it is how it is now.

107492: War's Toll.author: OmegaSerris
107492: War's Toll.text_parsed:
Yes, exactly. This is great against players. If they want to play something on their turn, no counterspells on yours. Same with , they can't leave defenders (other THAN defenders/walls) if they want to attack. It pretty much forces your opponent to play like a player, and 's enemy colors DO NOT enjoy that.

Even the ally colors wouldn't be all that happy. having to swing with it's mana bugs and having little access to it's combat tricks. not being able to mess with it's instant speed kill spells and having to swing it's littler, utility creatures (Royal Assassin, for example).

Yeah, nothing is guaranteed. They could tap utility creatures to keep them from attacking. And they could just leave their mana untapped to play things on your turn. But remember: If they tap out on your turn and play something, just changing phases will force them to empty what is left in their pool, leaving them crippled. My point is, they weren't planning to play that way. It is disruption, plain and simple. And what does disruption cause? Mistakes. Quite an interesting and unique card, really. 5/5

Oh, and for those needing ideas of what to do with this: Ball Lightning deck, easy. They can never attack if they want to absorb damage and they can never play spells if they want to tag your hasty creatures. Too bad it is a little slow for those decks, but the effects are perfect for it.

@Duddits
This has a shaky relationship with Mana Barbs. For one, no it doesn't force them to pull mana out of their lands. But if they want to play more than one spell, they HAVE to tap it all at once (in response to this triggering). So for draw spells, it creates a hard choice, tap out and take damage to have the option of playing a spell they just drew, or not. But on the other hand, the limited access to mana this creates means less spells/abilities they are tapping lands for, meaning the Barbs does potentially less damage than it would have anyway.

It pretty much forces your opponent to play like a [R] player, and [R]'s enemy colors DO NOT enjoy that. 

Even the ally colors wouldn't be all that happy. [G] having to swing with it's mana bugs and having little access to it's combat tricks. [B] not being able to mess with it's instant speed kill spells and having to swing it's littler, utility creatures ([autocard]Royal Assassin[/autocard], for example). 

Yeah, nothing is guaranteed. They could tap utility creatures to keep them from attacking. And they could just leave their mana untapped to play things on your turn. But remember: [u][b]If they tap out on your turn and play something, just changing phases will force them to empty what is left in their pool, leaving them crippled[/b][/u]. My point is, they weren't planning to play that way. It is disruption, plain and simple. And what does disruption cause? Mistakes. Quite an interesting and unique [R] card, really. 5/5 

Oh, and for those needing ideas of what to do with this: [autocard]Ball Lightning[/autocard] deck, easy. They can never attack if they want to absorb damage and they can never play spells if they want to tag your hasty creatures. Too bad it is a little slow for those decks, but the effects are perfect for it.

@Duddits
This has a shaky relationship with [autocard]Mana Barbs[/autocard]. For one, no it doesn't [i]force[/i] them to pull mana out of their lands. But if they want to play more than one spell, they HAVE to tap it all at once (in response to this triggering). So for draw spells, it creates a hard choice, tap out and take damage to have the option of playing a spell they just drew, or not. But on the other hand, the limited access to mana this creates means less spells/abilities they are tapping lands for, meaning the Barbs does potentially less damage than it would have anyway.

107492: War's Toll.author: TheWrathofShane
107492: War's Toll.text_parsed:
I am guessing how this works...
Opponent taps one land, and then this triggered ability goes on the stack.
When the ability resolves, all lands are tapped. So its up to you to tap for mana before the ability resolves.

interesting note, thats 5+ abilities triggering for each land they tap for mana. I cant think of a way to abuse right now, but I am sure there is one.

Also as a side-note, I wonder how this interacts with the "undo" button on MTGO. You tap land, trigger gos on the stack. You undo, does the land untap and trigger go away, or does it stop you from undoing.

107492: War's Toll.author: Tharios
107492: War's Toll.text_parsed:
A few things...

The card does not lock mana, but it does force players to "use it or lose it". They either tap lands so the acquisition of mana goes on the stack and resolves before the effect of War's Toll, or the lose access to it until their next untap phase. As others have pointed out, this means they can either case sorcery-type permanents, or they can cast instant-types; but never both while this enchantment is on the board.

This card isn't a terrific combination with Manabarbs, but it can be worth it. If your own deck is fast enough, they'll have to choose between being overrun by you, or potentially suiciding by Manabarbs.

I myself have these in a deck with 4 Nettling Curse, 4 Hissing Miasma, and an assortment of cards that prevent combat damage such as Darkness, and those that grant me temporary control of one or more of an opponent's creatures. I call it my Kevorkian deck. I plan to add better multi-lands, and eventually 4 Blood Reckoning also. It can be a touch on the slow side, and thus is best in group games, but it's still relatively quick and no slouch in duels.

War's Toll is still a greatly useful card, though it would be so much better if mana burn still existed.

107493: Kill-Suit Cultist.author: Mode
107493: Kill-Suit Cultist.text_parsed:
Still a far more useful crazed Goblin than Crazed Goblin itself, but i'm upset about the flaw this card got from the M10 rulings as well.
I really used to like that guy, but now since he isn't able to destroy his blocker anymore this card lost a lot of power...

Normally i don't complain about errata and rule changes, but some M10 rulings intended to simplify gameplay for beginners screwed up a lot of older cards.

What about that errata:
": The next time damage would be dealt to target creature this turn, destroy that creature instead. If you activated this ability during the combat step, sacrifice ~ at end of combat. Otherwise, sacrifice ~."
This should be added to about any pre-M10 creature with an activated ability that requires saccing it, but it's possibly to confusing to be added to them. Dang, i simply wish Wizars returned to the old rulings.

107504: Ghost Quarter.author: DarthParallax
107504: Ghost Quarter.text_parsed:
I recently designed a Desert World set where I tried to imagine a plane that was the opposite of Zendikar or Alara- very sparse mana, with no basic lands in the first set- (to teach people to really appreciate them when they were put in the second). Instead I used a kooky kind of mono colored painland cycle with the desert subtype. Not as painful as X Edition Duals, just painful enough to be nearly strictly worse than basic lands. And then I thought about making a special twist off of Strip Mine, called it Salt Mine, and I just realized- it was exactly the same card as Ghost Quarter, except it searched deserts instead of basics.

Desert Land Cycle template, in case anyone's interested:

White Desert

Land-Desert
Whenever cardname enters the battlefield tapped, you lose 1 life
T: Add W to your mana pool

With lots of effects in different colors (G, W, U, and Salt Mine) that got lands to enter the battlefield tapped, and not always in a Rampant Growth way.

And then I added a cool 'Arid' keyword that rewarded you for playing with deserts. Stuff like +1/+1 counters and tokens if you controlled/took pain from/tapped mana from deserts. Combined with Salt Mine, I was attempting to find a way to get people to use the Desert Lands, even though the Core Set would obviously keep the basics in rotation, and just take the pain, rather than try to avoid it, so they could experience what a Desert World might be like, but still be able to cast their spells and make decent decks. My idea for draft was to have the store's boxes of lands be deserts instead of basics.

I still don't know if Desert Lands are a good idea or not, but it's pretty obvious that Ghost Quarter is a very good template for fixed Strip Mine, and if anybody else is into custom sets, and they're thinking about messing around with something as fundamental as lands, then a Ghost Quarter variant should probably appear in your block.
107504: Ghost Quarter.text_posted:
I recently designed a Desert World set where I tried to imagine a plane that was the opposite of Zendikar or Alara- very sparse mana, with no basic lands in the first set- (to teach people to really appreciate them when they were put in the second). Instead I used a kooky kind of mono colored painland cycle with the desert subtype. Not as painful as X Edition Duals, just painful enough to be nearly strictly worse than basic lands.  And then I thought about making a special twist off of Strip Mine, called it Salt Mine, and I just realized- it was exactly the same card as Ghost Quarter, except it searched deserts instead of basics. 

Desert Land Cycle template, in case anyone's interested:

White Desert

Land-Desert
Whenever cardname enters the battlefield tapped, you lose 1 life
T: Add W to your mana pool

With lots of effects in different colors (G, W, U, and Salt Mine) that got lands to enter the battlefield tapped, and not always in a Rampant Growth way.

And then I added a cool 'Arid' keyword that rewarded you for playing with deserts. Stuff like +1/+1 counters and tokens if you controlled/took pain from/tapped mana from deserts.  Combined with Salt Mine, I was attempting to find a way to get people to use the Desert Lands, even though the Core Set would obviously keep the basics in rotation, and just take the pain, rather than try to avoid it, so they could experience what a Desert World might be like, but still be able to cast their spells and make decent decks. My idea for draft was to have the store's boxes of lands be deserts instead of basics.

I still don't know if Desert Lands are a good idea or not, but it's pretty obvious that Ghost Quarter is a very good template for fixed Strip Mine, and if anybody else is into custom sets, and they're thinking about messing around with something as fundamental as lands, then a Ghost Quarter variant should probably appear in your block.

107504: Ghost Quarter.author: ZestuXIII
107504: Ghost Quarter.text_parsed: I am SO happy this is getting reprinted in Innistrad. Getting a Basic Land really isn't all that much of a drawback. Consider killing their Inkmoth Nexus (or any other manland for that matter), or their dual lands or prism lands. With Zendikar out of the Standard picture, you won't have to worry about extra Landfall triggers, and Tectonic Edge essentially costs to activate. All things considered, I think this is a more than decent land removal option, especially for the soon-to-be Standard and quite possibly in Modern.

107506: Momir Vig, Simic Visionary.author: Lash_of_Dragonbreath
107506: Momir Vig, Simic Visionary.text_parsed:
I'm adding it to my Intet, the Dreamer EDH deck, since: a) it's mostly composed of creatures and lands, so playing a creature each turn shouldn't be much of a problem and b) it supposedly has a lot of sinergy with a lot of cards in it, such as Intet himself (it nets you a lot of value just for casting your commander, plus it combos fantastically with his ability), Djinn of Wishes, Garruk's Horde...
Other than those, it also turns any U/G creature into a tutor/draw spell (and there are quite few great U/G creatures: Coiling Oracle, Trigon Predator, Simic Sky Swallower, Nulltread Gargantuan...) AND gives you card advantage against counterspells. Pretty solid, as long as you've got the means to protect him (because, honestly, he's a little fragile for a 5 drop - but worry not, you can always run counterspells or, even better, Mystic Snakes or Plaxmantas).
Another thing I'd like to point out is that, whenever you cast a G/U creature spell, you can choose the order in which the effects trigger. So, if you somehow (and by "somehow" I mean Sphinx of Jwar Isle or Cream of the crop) know what's the next card in your library, you can put that card in your hand (if it's a creature) instead of the card you tutor for. This is nice to do in case you'd rather have that card on top of your library for some reason (and I generally do have a reason to want that).
Sorry for the long review, but I think Momir Vig is an awesome card and can't really shorten my ideas about him more than this. Also, look at Sages of the Anima for another great G/U combo card, although not as good as this.

107506: Momir Vig, Simic Visionary.author: drpvfx
107506: Momir Vig, Simic Visionary.text_parsed:
Quite possibly my most effective EDH General, and that surprised me a bit.
If I get him out with Fable of Wolf and Owl
(which is not too hard since the latter tends to be a low-priority target... at first),
things start getting out of control *very* quickly.

I'll cast something like Slippery Bogle, Vig fetches a Murkfiend Liege,
I cast the Liege and Vig fetches a Mystic Snake.
After countering a spell with Snake, I have 3 3/3 Wolf Tokens, 3 2/2 Flying Bird Tokens,
a 3/3 Hexproof Bogle, a 4/4 Snake, a 4/4 Liege, and a 4/4 Momir Vig.
And I *probably* fetched a Vedalken Mastermind to further abuse Mystic Snake.

This may sound far-fetched, but it's happened before.
Momir Vig is *not* to be underestimated!

107507: Cytoplast Root-Kin.author: kiseki
107507: Cytoplast Root-Kin.text_parsed:
Yes modular and hydra creatures auto-benefit, but don't forget spikes!
Both this and Spike Rogue work well with Protean Hydra:
Repeatably pay to get 2 more counters. (just after you play your heartstone)

Or curve a turn 3 suspended Fungal Behemoth into this to attack with a very large behemoth. Maybe your first or second turn drop was a graft creature too, so that it can receive the behemoth counter, and still graft to the behemoth so that this root-kin gives him a counter as well.
Don't ignore the fact that all that synergy is above and beyond the efficiency that this has naturally.
Compare with another strong card with similar applications: Fangren Firstborn

107517: Nihilistic Glee.author: exterion
107517: Nihilistic Glee.text_parsed:
Sure, the first ability is utter crap. While it may be used to cycle worthless cards (creature removal vs creatureless deck) for a small amount of life drain, three mana and a card simply isn't worth it.
However, the second ability is pretty decent and definitely upps this card's playability. You can activate it any number of times (as far as your life and mana permits) in response to each other to fill out your hand and essentially giving you a less color-restricted Greed when hellbent.

107534: Seal of Doom.author: achilleselbow
107534: Seal of Doom.text_parsed:
Yea, unless it says otherwise, activated abilities are played as instants. So it would be really stupid to try to Disenchant this.

I guess the way this is supposed to work is that if you have nothing else to cast on the third turn, but your opponent doesn't have anything to kill, you can just drop it and not worry about leaving mana open for a removal spell later on. Though in that case your opponent will probably try to trick you into wasting it on a lesser creature before he brings out his main threats. I can't imagine that this would be played as anything but a sorcery-speed Dark Banishing in 99% of cases.

Edit: I must now eat my words with the release of Emrakul, the Aeons Torn.

107534: Seal of Doom.author: Weary_PSI
107534: Seal of Doom.text_parsed: The big advantage of this card is that it's what Anthony Alongi used to call a "rattlesnake card", in that it discourages other players from attacking or using a creature's activated abilities against you. All in all, a delicate creature with a lot of uses and very powerful in the right deck.

4/5

107543: Rakdos Augermage.author: blurrymadness
107543: Rakdos Augermage.text_parsed:
Another neat card that's best with hellbent, but isn't actually hellbent. I used to think this was mediocre but looking at it from new Rakdos eyes (years later) I can see I actually should have a playset of these.

You can discard anything in their hand. Let that sink in. If your deck runs on 3-4 mana, this guy basically tears your opponent's hand apart if you haven't finished doing so already. He's not fast enough to be used as your primary discard and his defensive/offensive body doesn't synergize with his ability; however, it allows him to be useful all the time.

He's also 3 cost allowing for some really speedy plays with Unearth and Anger and a 1-mana discard outlet. Talk about tempo if you hit with a Dark Ritual! God hands aside, good luck facing that down if he nabs one of your starting lands..

107551: Weight of Spires.author: Palochka
107551: Weight of Spires.text_parsed:
Braid of Fire's Card of the Day #17

Weight of Spires is a very interesting card. Burn spells are hard to make because they are so linear in nature. Very often it's simply a numbers game, an attempt to find the best cost to power ratio and restrictions for the limited enviornment. This card stands out as a mechanically clever card in the context of Ravnica limited, where non-basic lands were the rule rather than the exception, even if there rarely were more than one or two Karoo variants on the other side of the table. Effectively costed and designed with adequate scaling in mind, Weight of Spires has a place in limited as a later pick burn spell, a strange plane for such a splashable card to be.

Clearly inspired by Price of Progress, Weight of Spires is rarely better than an instant-speed Flame Jab. Its constructed uses are limited due to its unreliability and that it's generally outclassed by Lightning Bolt's versatility. This card is generally just behind the curve by a point of damage or two with the rare basic that sneaks into tournament play with its efficient creatures and can be played around. Even Vendetta is more useful with its guarantee of getting the job done at the same mana cost.

All that being said, this is a very neat design with great Ravnica flavor. It has a home for sure in Rx Commander decks as cheap removal, as efficient spells are much better than people give them credit for in that format. The problem is that in Constructed there are just better cards.

107553: Muse Vessel.author: MisterAction
107553: Muse Vessel.text_parsed:
I love the idea of this card, so I built a monoblue deck around it. It takes awhile to get going, so it uses Desert to deter early attacks, and Man-o'-War and Aether Adept to stall by bouncing and then chump-blocking if needed. Counterspell comes in handy as well.

Fellwar Stone not only ensures you can cast their spells later on, but also accelerates your mana (you'll need a lot). Annex does the same, with the added bonus of the occasional mana-screw (on turn three if you get the stone out first). Vivid Creek is an extra bit of insurance in case you don't draw either of them.

This is a slow deck, not only because of the mana required but because at first your opponent can choose to exile spells that aren't useful to you. However, if you can survive until he/she is out of cards, you've all but won. Man-o'-War changes from a bouncer to outright theft. Boomerang will clear up any other permanents that may have slipped past you. If you want to press your luck you can even use Words of Wisdom to fetch something to steal, but it's not really that useful until you're already too far ahead for it to matter.

It's an entertaining deck, but be warned: there is no such thing as a close game with this deck. You will either be overwhelmed and pummeled into dust, or seize full control in a long drawn-out process that will make your opponent hate you, having abandoned all hope somewhere between having their lands stolen and having their face stomped by the very creatures they didn't have the mana to play. That intense, down-to-the-last-turn, outcome-depends-on-what-I-draw-next feeling that makes games memorable will never happen when you use this deck.

107562: Wit's End.author: Kirbster
107562: Wit's End.text_parsed:
Yeah, mass-discard spells like this just don't work. Like with Monomania and Amnesia, the mana cost is so prohibitively large that your opponent will likely have one or two cards, if that, by the time you can play it. All too often your seven-mana "bomb" will be countered by your foe commiting the ultimate counter-strategy that is "playing cards."

Really, though, the effect can't be much cheaper. Would this be playable at four mana? Yes, certainly. It would likely become broken, especially with even a hint of mana-acceleration. By turn seven, though, if you're opponent hasn't crossed the win-by-now-or-lose threshold, then he's probably in a position where he's set up some sort of lock. Mass discard necessitates a high mana cost but by its very nature is only useful early on.

That is why cheap, targeted denial - cards like Duress and Thoughtseize - see play again and again. One-for-one ratios of mana-to-discard are powerful, such in the case of Hymn to Tourach or Gerrard's Verdict. If Wit's End guaranteed seven discards, then things might be more interesting - even then, though... seven mana, yo. What this card wants to be is Mind Twist. It is playable at essentially any stage in the game, and you pay only what you need to to wipe out your opponent's hand.

I guess you could say Wit's End is... patheitc?

107562: Wit's End.author: grothesk
107562: Wit's End.text_parsed: I'm a bit surprised at the comments on this card, but maybe that's because I play too much group game casual.  This card is officially banned in our casual games because it's: A) Not fun to have your whole hand discarded, and B) far, far too powerful of an effect.  We like to play stupid huge creatures and late game sorceries so it's not very common to see a player with 4 to 6 cards in their hand on turn six and beyond.  In the casual environment I play in this card typically ends up being a 5 for 1, which is just too big of a swing in card advantage to allow.
107562: Wit's End.text_posted: I'm a bit surprised at the comments on this card, but maybe that's because I play too much group game casual.  This card is officially banned in our casual games because it's: A) Not fun to have your whole hand discarded, and B) far, far too powerful of an effect.  We like to play stupid huge creatures and late game sorceries so it's not very common to see a player with 4 to 6 cards in their hand on turn six and beyond.  In the casual environment I play in this card typically ends up being a 5 for 1, which is just too big of a swing in card advantage to allow.

I think this is better than Birds of Paradise in most mono green decks... while it doesnt have a body, its not as easy a target as birds is... only dicard enchantment can handle it while any creature removal, -1/-1 counter or effect can kill it, plus it can only block and will die once it does and you wont get the free mana anymore.

Of course birds of paradise is a more versatile card, being very splashable and allowing for a lot of decks to be viable, but for monogreen splashing something else while havging also acceleration, I think this is better.

Fertile ground is really cool to, but costing 1R it is down a notch IMO. Again, a lot more versatile and playable if youre not packing a bunch of forests.

5/5

107569: Utopia Sprawl.author: Grone
107569: Utopia Sprawl.text_parsed:
This card is better than Llanowar Elves and Birds of Paradise.
On any turn other than turn 1, this is essentially free to use. You can tap a forest, and then attach this to another forest. Then, tapping the second forest will yield 2 mana. This allows you to mana fix on the same turn that you play it, and it also gives you 1 extra mana in future turns. Llanowar and Birds, on the hand, require you to wait a turn before they start rewarding you.
Also, enchantments are harder to remove than creatures.
The only advantage that Llanowar Elves and Birds of Paradise have over this is that you can chump block with later in the game should circumstances require it. Other than that, utopia sprawl is much better.
5/5

107569: Utopia Sprawl.author: leomistico
107569: Utopia Sprawl.text_parsed:
AXER said:
"Lush Growth and Fertile Ground are much better. "

How can you sai it?
Fertile Ground costs more, losing the possibility of a 3CMC play in the 2nd turn. You have more flexibility with the mana color, but you lose in acceleration. And in a 2-color deck (like almost every deck you would build in Ravnica block) Utopia Sprawl is better, in my opinion.
Lush Growth doesn't give you acceleration and you can't have blue or black mana...
Those cards may be occasionally better than Utopia, but not so often and not so far, so I wouldn't say that "are MUCH better"...

The restriction is a little annoing, but if you're playing green for mana acceleration or mana fixing, then you should play quite a lot of Forest, so it isn't really a problem...
4/5

107569: Utopia Sprawl.author: DarthParallax
107569: Utopia Sprawl.text_parsed:
The comments on this card have reminded me that there are quite a few 'Enchant Land' auras.

I think if those were more common, Wizards would be forced to make 'destroy target land' easier to do.

As it is, these auras have a much lower probability of 'inherent aura card disadvantage'. I think that the appropriate thing to do is to divide it about 2/3 between Lush Growth and Utopia Sprawl in a deck with very difficult color requirements, and these auras should set you up up better than the creatures Alara gave us, or even Birds of Paradise and Lotus Cobra (being killable is really a heavy disadvantage).

8 Fetch Lands for the singleton Forest in your deck, plus these, plus 3 colors that can do something really really powerful (White-Black-Red Boom? Blue-Black-Red Bolas? Red-Blue-White Justice League Planeswalkers?).

107569: Utopia Sprawl.author: cadencetoarms
107569: Utopia Sprawl.text_parsed:
@blindthrall

It doesn't. From Imperiosaur's rules:

"Mana from any source other than a land with the supertype "basic" can't be spent to cast Imperiosaur. Many mana-producing effects (such as Heartbeat of Spring or Utopia Sprawl, for example) add mana to a player's mana pool whenever a land becomes tapped. This mana is produced by the enchantment, not the land, so it can't be used to pay for Imperiosaur."

107570: Ragamuffyn.author: HeartbreakerStudios
107570: Ragamuffyn.text_parsed:
This is very underrated. The ability to toss creatures AND lands in the grave for draw power is excellent for fueling sacrifice, graveyard recycling decks, Unearth, Dredge, and Madness. It being a Zombie also makes it very playable in Zombie decks too.

The two biggest problems are Hellbent (which definitely limits the card's playability somewhat except in Hellbent decks) and the art. It's not a very attractive card, the creature appears confusing if not nonsensical, and it doesn't even resemble a zombie.

If the art were better, I'd definitely get it, but as it stands, Ghoulraiser's much more preferable for theme decks.

107597: Taste for Mayhem.author: Kurraga
107597: Taste for Mayhem.text_parsed:
I like this card, becase it CAN make my deck win on turn 2, (without disruption)

Turn 1: Lay Mountain and play Goblin Guide, then exile Simian Spirit Guide to enchant it with Taste for Mayhem, and Swing for 4.

Now you should have 3 cards in hand.

Turn 4: Lay mountain, use 2 mountains and another Spirit Guide to cast Ball Lightning, and you should have 1 card in your hand (that you drew this turn). Now you can play your Fireblast, saccing your 2 mountains and putting your opponent on 12, as well as making Goblin Guide a 6/2, now swing with both your 6 power creatures for the win!

It never happens, but 1 mana for 6 damage going somewhere isn't bad, I think this card should be rated higher. 4.0 for me.

107598: Protean Hulk.author: Arachibutyrophobia
107598: Protean Hulk.text_parsed:
Does everyone know the turn zero win combo? In my opinion, it revolves around the protean hulk.

Anyway, if you don't know, I think I can list it here.

First play a Gemstone Mine or Gemstone Caverns.
Then exile Simian Spirit Guide from your hand.
Tap Gemstone Mine for blue mana and cast Flash, putting Protean Hulk into play, then sacrificing it.

From here, you can do a variety of things. But if you still want to win on turn zero, then first search for 4x Disciple of the Vault. Then 4x Shifting Wall and 4x Phyrexian Marauder. The eight artifacts die instantly and you can have an opponent lose 32 life.

I'm not sure why, but for some reason, this is all "turn zero".

There's a whole decklist for this combo, but I haven't memorized it...yet.

@person1234:

Either land will work.

You have to do it before your opponent's upkeep for it to be considered turn 0.

107598: Protean Hulk.author: Lateralis0ne
107598: Protean Hulk.text_parsed:
Opening Hand: (for optimal awesomeness)
1 Basic Land
1 Lotus Petal
1 Flash
1 Protean Hulk
2 Force of Will
1 Blue card of your choice

Play land, lotus, flash, hulk, search for:

4x Disciple of the Vaults (cost: 4)
4x Phyrexian Walker (cost: 0)
4x Ornithoptor (cost: 0)
4x Shield Sphere (cost: 0)
1x Arcbound Ravager (cost: 2)

drop them all, sac the 12 0 artifacts to the ravager, and target player loses 48 life. If you go first. Of course, force of wills are to counteract any force of wills on your own spells. Build your deck accordingly.

Happy Flashing, my friends.

107598: Protean Hulk.author: Arglypuff
107598: Protean Hulk.text_parsed:
Actually Arachibutyrophobia, the turn 0 combo ONLY works with Gemstone Cavern.

Scenario: You, Arachibutyrophobia, are on the play. So I get to put my Cavern into play immediately before your upkeep. Then, during your upkeep, perform the combo.

Scenario with Gemstone Mine: You, Arachibutyrophobia, are on the play. You play your turn (turn 1). Then I play my Mine, and then perform the combo. On turn 1. Because Gemstone Mine can't be in play until my first main phase.

107598: Protean Hulk.author: CeremonialBathory
107598: Protean Hulk.text_parsed:
@person1234 - Gemstone Cavern is the one with the luck counter and starts out in play under certain conditions. Gemstone Mine has "mining counters" on it and is not in play when the game starts.

@Arachibutyrophobia - He was explaining why it's "Turn 0". If you have Gemstone Cavern out with a luck counter, you can play all of it before their upkeep. Since you're going second (or at least not first) you haven't had your first turn yet - hence Turn 0. So, no. Gemstone Mine will not work to do it on "Turn 0".

107598: Protean Hulk.author: GrimjawxRULES
107598: Protean Hulk.text_parsed:
I'm not much of a 1st turn win-person, so my combo with Protean hulk and Flash would probably be something like:

T1: Mountain, Amulet of Vigor
T2: Island (or any Karoo-type land that adds - you may float the other land's mana), Flash the Hulk and drop Primeval Titan + 4 Dryad Arbor, search for some more lands with Titan's etb ability and cast Burst of Speed. You can choose to attack with or without the Dryads. If you choose not to, you'll have 7 untapped lands in your second main phase (8 if you floated a red land off the Mountain with a Karoo-land). If you choose to attack with the dryads, you'll have 3-4 untapped lands. Either way, you'll have enough mana to cast some additional spells before passing the turn, and you'll have swung for 6-10 dmg on your 2nd turn.

If you don't hit the jackpot and have all four cards in your hand, you can at least still flash the hulk into Primeval Titan and Dryads, in which case you'll start your 3rd turn with 8 mana untapped lest your opponent cleared the board somehow.
Idk, I just like the thought of being able to start my 3rd turn with 8+ mana by only using two cards. If you can manage to drop a Plains and a Steppe Lynx on your 1st turn instead of your Amulet of Vigor, you're in for some serious landfall on your next turn.

And I'm definitely speculating too much about flash-hulk combos...

107598: Protean Hulk.author: blurrymadness
107598: Protean Hulk.text_parsed:
Think of it as cascade except:
-You get to tutor the card
-If the first card isn't enough you may tutor another. Repeat this process.
-It occurs on death; which is more easily used/abused than casting.

Even without crazy T0 decks he can tutor and play a titan for you if he gets killed.
That's card advantage in green; which is a beautiful thing.

110641: Entropic Eidolon.text_parsed:
The thing people neglect about eidolons is that every single one of them works without you even having to play it. All you do is have a deck stuffed with multicolour which discards them for benefit. For example any card which allows you to draw one, discard one like a looter, or lore broker, anything like that, you will essentially end up drawing cards for free.

I have a deck which runs 8 of them and never plays them. Just uses them for free discard.

111188: Rakdos Pit Dragon.author: DoctorKenneth
111188: Rakdos Pit Dragon.text_parsed:
Never underestimate the power of firebreathing, evasion, and double strike on the same card. It can be, and very much is, a win condition. And don't kid yourself- if you're playing this right and including it among your Hellspark Elementals, Ball Lightnings, and Bolts, your hand will be empty very quickly. This guy WILL have double-strike. It's just a matter of getting in and using him quickly before your opponent has a chance to react.

I mean, a 3/3 for four is solid. A 3/3 for four with three useful abilties is an incredible deal, even if they're mana-intensive or conditional. I'm surprised this guy never warrented more attention- he's useful in anything red-heavy. He needn't be used in dragon tribal.

That said, Silverware, who plays dragon decks that aren't Dragonstorm?

111192: Aethermage's Touch.author: skew
111192: Aethermage's Touch.text_parsed: Forgeling: nope, casting this in opponents turn doesn't help. The creature still has the summonig sickenss. See rules, 302.6, summoning sickness.

111192: Aethermage's Touch.author: Mudbutt_on
111192: Aethermage's Touch.text_parsed:
You can still cast it on the opponent's turn to remove summoning sickness, read the rule again:

302.6. A creatures activated ability with the tap symbol or the untap symbol in its activation cost cant be activated unless the creature has been under its controllers control continuously since his or her most recent turn began. A creature cant attack unless it has been under its controllers control continuously since his or her most recent turn began. This rule is informally called the summoning sickness rule.
111192: Aethermage's Touch.text_posted:

111202: Wrecking Ball.author: pedrodyl
111202: Wrecking Ball.text_parsed:
Card of the Day, December 13th, 2012
Wrecking Ball is instant speed land destruction, of which you don't see much. I think this is probably because some players would try to destroy a land in response it being tapped for mana, which you can't do, and so to avoid the whole confusion, Wizards usually prints sorcery speed LD. The same type of deal goes for instant speed discard, which is also pretty rare (as in, not that common, er, not that frequently appearing on cards...)
Nowadays you hardly see any good LD getting printed. There is usually about one spell per set that takes care of lands, and it is usually pretty unplayable. This is sad because there are some pretty outrageous lands out there in standard (I'm looking at you, Cavern of Souls and shocklands). But I guess land destruction just isn't fun. Or even necessary. Just let everyone play 5 colors with no circumstances whatsoever, huh?
Oh, and this card destroys creatures, too?

111204: Simic Sky Swallower.author: MacBizzle
111204: Simic Sky Swallower.text_parsed:
I would play this guy even if he had been priced at 8 mana. He is quite big, has TWO forms of evasion (trample is a green evasion) and he has an unbiased protection, which barely makes him balanced. A really powerful card, but not a broken card. He is how I rate a deck's versatility.
"I see your win condition, I see your essentials, I see your removal... but can you theoretically (with the right hand) handle a Simic Sky Swallower?"

You wrath, you evacuate and discard or you play a flier/reacher that can kill him upon blocking.

Wing Shards would also work, though you'd be making your opponent a better player by reminding them to play everything on their second main phase.

"I see your win condition, I see your essentials, I see your removal... but can you theoretically (with the right hand) handle a Simic Sky Swallower?"

You [autocard multiverseid="129808"]wrath[/autocard], you [autocard multiverseid="129541"]evacuate[/autocard] and [autocard multiverseid="7168"]discard[/autocard] or you play a [autocard multiverseid="265156"]flier[/autocard]/[autocard multiverseid="370582"]reacher[/autocard] that can kill him upon blocking.

[autocard]Wing Shards[/autocard] would also work, though you'd be making your opponent a better player by reminding them to play everything on their second main phase.

By investing some mana into Coat of Arms, you can use any of the combos listed here for a huge army of powerful defenders. Use the RotE enchantment to cause creatures to lose flying when attacking, and then throw down something that shares a type with this, and you're in business.

Protean Hydra or Phytohydra would be my recommendations, by the way, though Phytohydra breaks the pure Green theme.

111220: Sprouting Phytohydra.author: KikiJikiTiki
111220: Sprouting Phytohydra.text_parsed:
When combined with Pestilence/Pyrohemia damage done multiple times in the same turn, the plants reproduce following the fibonacci sequence.

Start with 1 plant - > 1 damage makes another plant=2 -> 2 damage kills the first plant, but makes 2 more=3 -> 3 damage kills the second but makes 3 more=5 ->4 damage kills two but makes 5 more=8...

111220: Sprouting Phytohydra.author: Jeckman
111220: Sprouting Phytohydra.text_parsed:
Fun math fact I just discovered: If you use Pestilence or Pyrohemia repeatedly, starting from a single plant, the number of plants you have after each activation of the damage ability (all in a single turn) follows the Fibonacci sequence: 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21, etc. The number of damaged plants you have also follows the sequence, and lags behind by two elements. In other words, if you have produced 21 plants, 8 of those would be damaged.

I'll leave the proof of this as an exercise to the reader.
111220: Sprouting Phytohydra.text_posted:
Fun math fact I just discovered: If you use [autocard]Pestilence[/autocard] or [autocard]Pyrohemia[/autocard] repeatedly, starting from a single plant, the number of plants you have after each activation of the damage ability (all in a single turn) follows the Fibonacci sequence: 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21, etc.  The number of damaged plants you have also follows the sequence, and lags behind by two elements.  In other words, if you have produced 21 plants, 8 of those would be damaged.

I'll leave the proof of this as an exercise to the reader.

There really needs to be a term for the increasing toughness like this.
Fire breathing, or water pumping depending on the color, for increasing attack...

111247: Flaring Flame-Kin.author: majinara
111247: Flaring Flame-Kin.text_parsed:
Reminds me on Thran Golem. The effect is strong, but only makes sense with very good auras. Most auras ain't worth it. The problem is that this guy dies very easly. Any Shock can kill it in response to you playing the aura, as does of course most other types of removal. Maybe a Sleepers Robe, since this guy then gain's evasion and draws you cards. Or a Squee's Embrace, making the removal of this guy not so painful.

Still, most of the time, it will be killed in response to or shortly after you played the aura, leaving you with card disadvantage.

83737: Omnibian.author: JaxsonBateman
83737: Omnibian.text_parsed:
@Talizmelf - that's because it DOES keep its abilities. If Omnibian uses its ability on Vigean Hydropod, it beceoms an 8/8 that can't attack or block.

The reason Aven Mimeomancer says is rather than becomes is because its a static ability that applies on all turns (as long as Mimeomancer stays around on the battlefield, thus supplying the ability). Omnibian needs to keep changing the target creature/s each time it uses its activated ability, and thus it uses "becomes".

If something wants to remove abilities, it's worded like Snakeform: Target creature loses all abilities and becomes a 1/1 green Snake until end of turn. Also note how it says becomes? =)

The merits of this land should be fairly obvious, I just wanted to add something that might not be:

This card looks AMAZING in foil.

It's the second most expensive foil card I own (after Mana Crypt),
but it is, by far, the most beautiful foil card I own-
the fountain comes alive, the lighting shines,
and the depth really pops.

And like all foil guild cards, the guild watermark is especially prominent.

tl;dr- as expensive as it was, this was worth every penny. Best looking foil I own, no question.

97073: Slaughterhouse Bouncer.author: Ferlord
97073: Slaughterhouse Bouncer.text_parsed:
Hellbent usually works when it activates while casting or a static ability. Demon's Jester is a decent Hellbent card because you can somewhat control the Hellbent-ness, giving you the chance to do all kinds of combat tricks.
For example, if you had one card in your hand (let's say Shock) and your opponent was going to attack with a 5/5 flyer (Serra Angel is a good example). Expecting just a 2/2 flying blocker, they don't think too much of it. However, to empty your hand, you cast Shock. This would make Jester into a 4/3, which can then kill Serra Angel when blocking. Limited gold!

The problem here is that Hellbent activates once, and not at a time that you can control as well. Sometimes your opponent won't block-to-kill it; sometimes they will kill it when you have 2+ cards in your hand; sometimes they'll consider killing it when they have no creatures in play, forcing you to target your own creature.

Long story short, it's a decent limited card, but it's by no means good. 2.5/5, where 1 star comes from the art.

Overcosted? 3 mana is par with the course for pingers. If it had cost 2, he'd have been overpowered. I think he's actually better than many pingers; you don't have to choose between hitting the player and hitting the creature- the Ickspitter lets you do both.

I know, sometimes he'll fall flat. He's dependent on the opponent having a targetable creature out there, but Rakdos is all about risk, isn't it? And how often do you see a blank field on the other side?

97075: Whiptail Moloch.text_parsed:
"Growers"
Protean Hydra
Phytohydra

Token generators
Broodhatch Nantuko
Saber Ants
Sekki, Seasons' Guide
Tuktuk the Explorer (if they didn't block him)
Rukh Egg

Damage redirectors
Coalhauler Swine
Spitemare (+ Mogg Maniac, Stuffy Doll, etc)

Misc.
Academy Rector
Body Snatcher
Mindslicer (good for hellbent?)
Act of Treason + other creature-stealers

So there are probably more interactions than people think, but nevertheless pretty slim pickings. Still, I think this is a mediocre rather than horrible card. Obviously not tournament-viable, but you could probably make some funky casual deck using it.

[autocard]Academy Rector[/autocard]
[autocard]Body Snatcher[/autocard]
[autocard]Mindslicer[/autocard] (good for hellbent?)
[autocard]Act of Treason[/autocard] + other creature-stealers

So there are probably more interactions than people think, but nevertheless pretty slim pickings. Still, I think this is a mediocre rather than horrible card. Obviously not tournament-viable, but you could probably make some funky casual deck using it.

97077: Azorius Guildmage.author: majinara
97077: Azorius Guildmage.text_parsed:
Got her in more decks than any other guildmage.
It's easy to play in matters of mana cost, 2/2 is a fine body for that as well, wizard is a creature type that is buffed by many other cards (azami, lady of scrolls for example), it can tap multiple creatures at instant speed and even the turn it comes into play.
The best though is the ability to counter activated abilities. Be it the card-draw effect of cycling, someone trying to pop a pernicious deed, trying to sac an aura of silence, mindslavering you or whatever. This guy can stop it all. :)

97077: Azorius Guildmage.author: Lyoncet
97077: Azorius Guildmage.text_parsed:
Hey, it's like they put Stifle on a (very shapely) stick and made it not broken! 3 CMC to activate is a bit restrictive, but since almost all active abilities come from permanents (cycling being one exception) you should pretty much always know just how much mana to hold aside.

In most cases I'd rather run Pithing Needle, but between the tap ability and being able to as many abilities (and different cards) as you have mana for, she's certainly far from outclassed. Also compliments Meddling Mage very well in that if a major threat or two slip in before you get out your Mage, you can still likely nullify a the card without having to use a kill or bounce.

97077: Azorius Guildmage.author: MacBizzle
97077: Azorius Guildmage.text_parsed:
She really isn't that shapely. She's a b cup, tops. I'd call her build "lanky", actually.

I love her. My favorite guildmage, her abilities are arguably better than the rest of the guildmages (save Izzet Guildmage for infinite mana production capability and Simic Guildmage for aura related shenanigans), and her abilities are really economically priced. She's got half a stifle with a reusable aspect, and she's got a tap that doesn't require her to tap.

I also love her aesthetics. She looks tired and bored, which, when combined with the completely-stall-the-game abilities, really adds to the bureaucratic flavor of Azorius.

97078: Simic Guildmage.author: Donovan_Fabian
97078: Simic Guildmage.text_parsed: Depending on the deck its actually a rather limited card, but good for being what it is, at a 2/2 body for 2 mana and some good utility.  As alphamoose pointed out, you can use it to exchange enchantments like shielding plax to another creature when its targeted by an instant, thus giving all your creatures pretty much instant shroud for 2 mana.  You can also use the minor boosting effect on a creature in combat, boosting its attack power to kill off an enemy creature by moving a counter onto it.  For an enchantment deck pair with kitsune mystic, who can also steal enchantments from your opponents, or move them back and forth.  Outside of enchantment/simic decks the utility breaks down a bit, as you may not have any enchantments to move, or making one creature bigger by weakening your other creature isn't a good use of 2 mana and a creature slot, especially for green where many boost cards are available.  It could be used in a jund deck to move counters onto creatures like mycoloth, but then again it also doesn't fit the aggro side of a jund deck very well.

97078: Simic Guildmage.author: LordRandomness
97078: Simic Guildmage.text_parsed:
Use it to shuffle Mind Controls around. This has multiple benefits:

- It doesn't target the permanent, only the aura. You can control hexproof stuff (sadly, still not protection)
- If something comes under your control, however briefly, it stops attacking. You can rapidly blink the mind control around enemy creatures to take several out of the attack and keep the one you want to keep.
- You can do the shuffle on their end step, meaning you get to untap and attack with the creature as soon as you get it.

Hell, I'm planning to run this in mono-blue =/

Additionally, make sure to have a Shielding Plax floating around so you can dump hexproof on things when they need it.

97082: Rakdos Carnarium.author: Gabriel422
97082: Rakdos Carnarium.text_parsed:
These lands are deceptively powerful. The drawbak is essentially "enters the battlefield tapped" and nothing more, because of the following scheme:

T1, 1 mana
T2, play Rakdos Carnarium, still 1 mana from the untap land you bounce
T3, 3 mana

Which is the same progression as if you played a etbt land like Savage Lands on Turn 2.

The reward, however, is that you just made three mana out of two cards. This is +1 card advantage, and so in raw power each land in this cycle is comparable to:

Land
Enters the battlefield tapped.
When it enters the battlefield, draw a card. (+1 CA)
Tap: add 1.

And wow, now it sure looks powerful! With some ramifications, of course, such as its color-fixing capability and that you risk drawing too much / too little mana (since they come two at a time), but then again +1 CA is +1 CA.
No wonder lots and lots of decks play a number of these lands back in the day, aggro and control alike!

97084: Shielding Plax.author: Antedelluvian
97084: Shielding Plax.text_parsed: I have a question? If say, you were to place Shielding Plax on a creature and it had Pacifism on it already. Would the Pacifism be put in to the graveyard at end of turn?
97084: Shielding Plax.text_posted: I have a question? If say, you were to place Shielding Plax on a creature and it had Pacifism on it already. Would the Pacifism be put in to the graveyard at end of turn?

97084: Shielding Plax.author: cadenblade
97084: Shielding Plax.text_parsed:
No because it retains any auras or counters attached to it. There are easy ways of getting rid of Pacifism tho. If you can get rid of the enchantment with something as cheap as Demystify, you can always return the creature to your hand using Unsummon or to your library with Nulltread Gargantuan.

I like this card because it takes away the negative drawback that shroud creates in not letting you beef up your creature when suddenly its cornered by something bigger than it. The draw card ability is a nice perk; I just wish this cost 1+b/g instead of 2+b/g and make it an uncommon.

Yeah, this is a great card for Lorescale Coatl, which comes into play with a big target on it for its ability. Other fun quick ways to pump the snake is to have a creature power 5 or greater and Drumhunter since you will be drawing cards 2x a turn. Rhystic Study is another good option since you can draw a card anytime an opponent casts a spell but not always reliable because they can pay that additional one mana to prevent it( especially against decks that have a lot of cheap costing white cards). A fun way to really spike up the counters on the Coatl is to drop a Soul's Majesty on any large powered creature you control. There are all kinds of combos and other cards to use tho. The snake is b/g for a good reason esp since blue deals a lot with cycling.

97084: Shielding Plax.author: monkeymonk42
97084: Shielding Plax.text_parsed:
@Mode

It's not hexproof. If it were hexproof and you put it on an opponents creature, you wouldn't be able to target it, since they control the creature and you are the opponent. However, you still control the enchantment even if it is on an opponents creature which means the "opponent" it's referring to in the card is still your opponents, not yourself. So you can target it but an opponent cannot.

I don't know in what situation you might want to do that instead of just using some kind of removal, but it is an important distinction from hexproof. Its more like opponent proof.

97084: Shielding Plax.author: EnderofGames
97084: Shielding Plax.text_parsed:
@mode, and the others who are wondering:

The reason the oracle text didn't change the rules to "Hexproof" is, as with all other auras, that you can enchant an enemy creature. If you gave them hexproof, then you wouldn't be able to target that creature again, but with THIS ability, THEY can't target it, even if it is their creature.

97084: Shielding Plax.author: flight_173
97084: Shielding Plax.text_parsed:
I have an instant rush infect deck that's basic principle is based of 1 and 2 drop infect weaklings that I then pump with spells. This card would shut it down if played on one of my guys. Here's some of the included cards. It should give you a good idea of what I'm talking about.

Pump Boosts:
Livewire Lash
Wild Defiance

Pumps:
Rancor
Might of Old Krosa
Prey's Vengeance
Virulent Swipe
Mutagenic Growth

Targets:
Glistener Elf
Inkmoth Nexus

It would especially hurt for Prey's Vengeance,Virulent Swipe. Also Rancor falls of Inkmoth Nexus and returns to the hand. This wouldn't help to much against that but it could still be useful as an anti block method if I made Inkmoth Nexus a creature too soon.
