97084: Shielding Plax.author: Mode
97084: Shielding Plax.text_parsed:
I wonder why the Oracle wording of this card did not change to "Enchanted creature has hexproof."

Edit (since 7/23/2011):
"The reason the oracle text didn't change the rules to "Hexproof" is, as with all other auras, that you can enchant an enemy creature. (...)" -- EnderofGames

Duh! Of course. Same as with Spirit Link back then when lifelink had an equal wording.
Else the card would have used the following unlikely unnecessarily convoluted wording:
"Enchanted creature has 'This creature can't be the target of spells or abilities your opponents control.'".

(I guess that's a little downside from having troll shroud keyworded now; we probably won't be getting an Aura like Shielding Plax anymore that has that effect on itself instead of providing the creature with it.)

I never thought of that, but you could even profit from casting it on your opponent's creatures in some cases - e.g. if they have an Heroic triggered ability that you don't want them to make use of, like Anax and Cymede.
97084: Shielding Plax.text_posted:

97087: Azorius Chancery.author: majinara
97087: Azorius Chancery.text_parsed:
Those bounce-lands are great in combination with lands with a CIP ability, or cycling lands like Barren Moor. In the early game, you can play the barren more if you are low on lands. Later you tap it, bounce it with one of these bounce-lands, and use the mana you got from tapping the moor to cycle it.

Of course, if one of these bounce lands gets destroyed, bounced or stolen, the tempo loss is plain horrible. Also, don't put too many of these in your deck. A starting hand with 3 bounce lands is something you surely don't want to see.

97092: Walking Archive.author: Bandswithother

I was once in a four player free for all where a guy had a deck built around this. He used a single contagion clasp (this was before scars so its all he had) to pump his archive giving us all sorts options that we could only look at thanks to his lodestone golems, and whenever we did get something rolling he would just All is Dust. He never lost tempo or decked out thanks to Elixir of Immortality; the life gain did help him, and he would always re-draw an All is Dust. He also used Obelisk of Alara just for the life boost.

Earlier in the game I had ***ed him off, so when I went to attack a different opponent he used Fate Transfer on my pumped Kazandu Bladmaster to give his counters to one of my opponents creatures.

97092: Walking Archive.author: Mode
97092: Walking Archive.text_parsed:
This is another severe case of "Love the flavor, hate tha card" for me.

If only this had a cost of , didn't have defender or at least was 2/2.
As an artifact creature it's more fragile to removal than Howling Mine, so i don't like having to pay ,
especially since it still lets your opponent draw the card first. It's a 2 for 1 trade (or merely a 1 for 0 trade) when your opponent casts a removal spell in his/her next turn.

At least you can add the counters on instant speed, so you get the first extra card when you make it grow.
Still, it wouldn't have hurt to reduce some of the costs, or let it attack (since getting this big is very costy).

It should be a fun Commander card, though.

Completely useless as far as competitive is concerned but a fun combo for casual.

97093: Evolution Vat.author: DarthParallax
97093: Evolution Vat.text_parsed:
Thromok the Insatiable, Riku of Two Reflections, Spatial Merging into Doubling Season + Furnace of Rath, Selesnya Loft Gardens, Stronghold Furnace, Rite of Replication, Infinite Reflection, Ambush Commander, and Mirror Gallery. Destroy Infinite Reflections somehow, then Avatar of Slaughter.



Result: your Kicked Rite of Replications copies one of your Forest/Elves, which you tapped for mana to power Riku's ability to copy creatures (they might be Ravnica Dual Forests) putting lots of Forest/Elves into play- which are all entering the battlefield as Legend-Rule-Does-Not-Apply Thromoks. Who can each have:

4x^2 counters on them (Doubling Season, Selesnya Plane, Thromok's base ability)

they deal 4x damage thanks to (Stronghold Furnace + Furnace of Wrath), so it's like 16(X^2) damage

there are at least 2 of them if all you did was Riku once, but if you did Ambush Commander/Rite of Replication/Infinite Reflections, there might be quite a lot of them out, especially if you find the right order of abilities to let Riku make lots and lots of copies because you are copying land/creatures.
Mirror Gallery is almost no-need-to-mention, but just to make sure...

Oh yeah, and now might be a good time to say I just remembered that another Infinite Reflections + Precursor Golem should work the way you want it to, and if it doesn't, you can just House Rules Errata it to. :p

Anyway, back to doubling things. So Gisela, Blade of Goldnight is fine, sure, but why not go the extra mile, and say 'Avatar of Slaughter'? If you are feeling ballsy, the ultimate enchantment to go with this is Hive Mind

The final damages are......

My calculator gave me this for a number: (turn calculator upside down.)

i45VW5 >11n4


Wait I forgot to say when to activate Evolution Vat. Oh, you get the point x.x

97094: Windreaver.author: trancebam
97094: Windreaver.text_parsed:
While it's still one of my favorite artworks, due to the new rules changes (which I don't disagree with), I'll probably never play him again. He used to fly in without hesitance or remorse, because nothing could touch him (except counterspells). Now he flies in hesitantly, and probably won't hit as hard. Who will own the skies now that Windreaver has been crippled?

@Zulp: that would probably be better to ask on the forums. I keep my copy because it's amazing artwork. Probably my favorite artwork period. But the reason he used to be amazing is because you could pump his toughness, switch his P/T, swing, and if your opponent blocked, stack the damage, then switch the P/T back, killing your opponent's creature and leaving Windreaver to fight another day. Now he's simply overcosted and underpowered.

97094: Windreaver.author: majinara
97094: Windreaver.text_parsed:
On the one hand I like him. On the other...
Giving vigilance for one white mana is weird. Normaly you'd expect abilities that can be activated multiple times this way to become stronger when activated multiple times. Giving vigilance multiple times makes no sense though, so it's a very weird choice.

And all in all, the M10 rules changes (which were horrible and just a step backwards) completly killed that card. It wasn't that great before M10 either but now it's just garbage. To those wondering why:
Let's say someone attacks you with a 5/5 dragon. You pump this guy up to 1/6 with his +0/+1 ability and switch it's p/t with it's other ability, so it's 6/1. Then you put the combat damage on the stack. The dragons controller assigns 5 to the windreaver, and you assign 6 to the dragon. Before the combat damage resolves you flip the Windreavers p/t again and now it's a 1/6. The dragon dies, beeing dealt 6 damage while having only 5 toughness, the windreaver lives, having been dealt 5 damage while beeing 1/6.

Doesn't work anymore. Man I despise those rule changes. -.- 2/5 stars now.

97096: Voidslime.text_parsed:
@typezeroserodin

Voidslime does not work on Iona, as her ability is static, and not triggered. You can tell this because it uses the word "As" rather than "When". You need you counter her, or else her ability will simply resolve when she does.

Voidslime does not work on Iona, as her ability is static, and not triggered.  You can tell this because it uses the word "As" rather than "When".  You need you counter her, or else her ability will simply resolve when she does.

97096: Voidslime.author: SevesDariku
97096: Voidslime.text_parsed:
I love seeing universally useful cards (like Counterspell/Cancel) get another card stapled on that isn't QUITE good enough to earn a slot in most decks, but is still useful.

Voidslime here is an excellent example of this. It's hard to justify running Stifle (except maybe sideboarding) despite what it COULD do, cause there are just too many decks it does nothing against. This card though? For the price of a colorful cancel, you can still do all the counterspelling you love, but have an unexpected answer for all those little abilities your opponents forget can be countered.

That being said... Render Silent is still my favorite counterspell of all time.

97099: Novijen, Heart of Progress.author: Mode
97099: Novijen, Heart of Progress.text_parsed:
Notice the "each" in the land's wording.
This might make this card especially useful if you run it in a deck that gets out many creatures at once, which will most often be a deck running tokens.
Snake Basket for example is such a card. Given that you have seven lands, you could then either decide to put seven 1/1 snakes into play, or only four of them and make them 2/2.
97099: Novijen, Heart of Progress.text_posted:

97100: Hellhole Rats.author: achilleselbow
97100: Hellhole Rats.text_parsed: This is comparable to Bloodbraid Elf. On the plus side, it gives guaranteed card advantage, whereas with the Elf there's a chance you'll cascade into something unplayable; on the minus side, it has one less power. On the plus side, it has the potential to deal a hefty amount of damage; on the minus side, the opponent could just discard a land. But by turn four it becomes less likely that they're holding a land, and more likely that they're holding high CC cards that they're waiting to cast. I'd say it's about a tie.

With sweet art curtisy of Kev Walker, you should see this card foil!

97100: Hellhole Rats.author: Aremath
97100: Hellhole Rats.text_parsed:
@Kryptnyt: He did, but it sucked:
Aquus Steed

@Ninjaraken: Much better. The random element of singe-mind is sometimes relevant, but this card actually makes them discard, which means that your opponent has to make a (mostly difficult) choice, and in terms of cards, this is card-neutral immediately once it hits the field. As to the bodies, I'd rather have a 2/2 haste than a 3/2 for the most part. The haste makes it more likely to connect since it is a surprise. Keep in mind that the ogre first gets to attack on turn 5. The chance your opponent can't get a bigger creature in the way on 5 mana is low.


Burndiscard is a really cool thing. The hope is that you've disrupted their hand enough at this point that they have to discard a land they really need, or discard a spell they can cast normally, or discard a big dude that will burn them for a lot. Blightning T3 into this puts your opponent into a pretty bad spot, handwise, lifewise, or both.

That said, it is a 2/2 for 4. The body is a little disappointing. Overall, I've had it shine, and I've had it be awful. It depends on when you draw it. When it hits the battlefield turn 4, generally it's good. Sometimes you can catch your opponent with an almost empty hand on a later turn and the discard gets them for 6 or even 7. Later in the game, often they just cast whatever instant they were holding in response to the discard.

Overall, sweet, but not amazing.

97101: Azorius First-Wing.author: yyukichigai
97101: Azorius First-Wing.text_parsed:
Such an awesome card. A 2/2 flyer for 2 is pretty good, even with the multicolor requirement. Then you throw in the seemingly random protection from enchantments and you've got something really solid. There's the obvious O-Ring and Journey, but then there's all the little random cards that you don't think about until it comes up. Powerstone Minefield got you down? Send your griffin buddy over it to express your displeasure to your opponent more directly. Being Pestilenced into oblivion? Slap a Pariah's Shield on Señor Azorius and tell that pesky plague to suck it.

Now if only Wizards would print more Griffins that were this good. Griffin Canyon, Zuberi, Golden Feather, and Griffin Rider are support cards in search of a tribal at the moment.

97104: Plaxcaster Frogling.author: Pongdok
97104: Plaxcaster Frogling.text_parsed: It's a toss-up between this and Omnibian for favourite frog. Luckily, there is no reason to choose between them when making a deck. Frogling is fantastic. He doesn't look too threatening on his own, but when he starts dishing out shroud to your other creatures, your opponent starts wondering if maybe he should have used some removal when this guy was vulnerable a few turns back. It can also fizzle spells your opponent casts on his own creatures (with appropriate counters) if he didn't read your unassuming little frog carefully. Great flavour, cheap and useful. 5/5

97105: Pain Magnification.author: Vinifera7
97105: Pain Magnification.text_parsed:
@majinara
Sorry to burst your bubble, but it's not a chain reaction. A single Megrim only deals 2 damage when they discard. Even if you have two Megrims out it won't turn into a chain reaction because Pain Magnification states that the opponent must be dealt 3 or more damage from a single source. Each Megrim is a separate source.
97105: Pain Magnification.text_posted:
@majinara
Sorry to burst your bubble, but it's not a chain reaction. A single Megrim only deals 2 damage when they discard. Even if you have two Megrims out it won't turn into a chain reaction because Pain Magnification states that the opponent must be dealt 3 or more damage from a [i]single source[/i]. Each Megrim is a separate source.

97105: Pain Magnification.author: Japicx
97105: Pain Magnification.text_parsed:
I was going to point out the combo that Esperlord just mentioned, but he beat me to it.

But still, Pain Magnification + Furnace of Rath + Megrim = "Whenever an opponent discards a card, that player discards his or her hand and is dealt 4 damage for each card discarded." Now there's a situation that should tilt the game in your favour.

Considering that this is a Rakdos card, it can also help you achieve hellbent when you take damage. Sadly, a disappointingly small number of cards make hellbent truly seem worth the effort. Anthem of Rakdos, Demonfire and Rakdos Pit Dragon seem the best to me. Gibbering Descent is good too, but only as a combo piece, albeit a very strong combo piece, considering the many black cards that require you or every player to sacrifice something, lose life or discard cards during upkeep.

Red-black is all about one thing and one thing only: hurting people. This card makes sure it happens, and it does a good job of it too.

97105: Pain Magnification.author: Justice1337
97105: Pain Magnification.text_parsed: Note, this card only affects opponents. Bad in that it doesn't let you discard when you take damage, for whatever reason you would want to do that, but good in that it's very effective in multiplayer. Just putting it down and doing nothing will cause at least 6 or 7 cards worth of discard through the course of an FFA EDH game, as everyone attacks the player who just played Vorinclex and your opponents hack it out amongst themselves. It becomes even better still when you're running a lot of 3 power creatures, like Beast tokens from Garruk Wildspeaker or Graveborn tokens from Sek'Kuar, Deathkeeper. In fact, it's almost good enough to be in every EDH deck that's into these colors. It's that good.

97106: Coiling Oracle.author: Bazooka99
97106: Coiling Oracle.text_parsed: I wish they would use this improved card draw mechanic more often. (New keyword mechanic for Magic 2013, perhaps?) Being able to play lands immediately after drawing them makes revealing one less of a disappointment, and a significant advantage during the first few turns. So far we've only seen the Coiling Oracle mechanic repeated in Skyward Eye Prophets and Your Fate Is Thrice Sealed. There's so much more that could be done with it, though: sorceries that go 2-3 cards deep; an improved Ophidian; maybe even an enchantment that turns all your draws into Coiling Oracle draws.

97106: Coiling Oracle.author: WarioMan
97106: Coiling Oracle.text_parsed:
I've always been a Simic freak since I saw the guild, what it stood for, and its colors. I've always tried fitting this dude into every deck I could because of its ability, which is essentially cantripping but better. With the advent of Gatecrash some really cool Elves that can have synergy with the other popular elf creatures (Joraga Warcaller, Master Biomancer working REALLY well with the +1/+1 elves like Elvish Archdruid) I decided to make a GU Elf deck. I had space for like 2 cards so I hastily poked through my GU stuff and came across this guy forgetting it was an Elf because it was never relevant before to me and cast it aside. I go on here to look up good elf cards as options and out comes this guy. I take a second look and notice "HOLY S*** IT'S AN ELF." and made room for 4 of these dudes. This is just such an amazing card.

5/5 for arbitrarily being an Elf as well as being a kickass card in any situation.

97106: Coiling Oracle.author: SevesDariku
97106: Coiling Oracle.text_parsed:
For anyone complaining about the reveal effect, instead of the "look" effect, this is prettymuch the way every card like this works. If a card cantrips but either does, or has the chance to do something special depending on the card you draw, you will reveal it. As far as I can tell, it's mostly to remove the possibility of cheating, but also to provide a small downside in letting your opponent know what you got.

As far as 'put into your hand' instead of 'draw a card'... Eh, you got me. Technically it can also be a good thing, as it prevents harassment from cards like Notion Thief, Pain Seer, Underworld Dreams, Nekusar, the Mindrazer, Spirit of the Labyrinth, and so on...
Mind you, I'm not saying that balances it out (as there are FAR more cards YOU can have that benefit from drawing, than cards your opponent will have that punish drawing), but just throwing it out there.

97109: Sky Hussar.author: Mode
97109: Sky Hussar.text_parsed:
Even if this card had nothing but its Forecast ability it would still be somewhat useful.
Drawing cards without paying mana? At any time!
Of course this won't work at instant speed in your opponent's turn when you don't mind tapping your creatures anymore, but even only being able to activate the ability once in your upkeep is worth it.

On top of that you won't find that much for white that provides card advantage.
Turning two of your white and/or blue creatures into archivists is an opportunity definitely worth considering in creature-heavy decks, those with tokens (e.g. when using Conqueror's Pledge) in particular.

And the cip/etb trigger works just great with this ability as well:
You'll effectively get a 4/3 flying body for five mana as cantrip.

And there's still more to it regarding his vitalizing trigger, since it untaps any creatures aside from just those you tapped for his Forecast ability - there are plenty of cratures with handy activated abilities that just require tapping!
When splashing green those which provide mana accel (like Birds of Paradise, Noble Hierarch or Bloom Tender for instance) will do a fabulous job with it.
You could also simply use it after combat to untap creatures which attacked that turn.

Great card, really makes me want to build a suiting deck when i look at it.

97109: Sky Hussar.author: Kruggles
97109: Sky Hussar.text_parsed:
@Burn - "Q: If I have multiple copies of the same card with Forecast in my hand, can I activate the Forecast ability multiple times?
A: You can activate the forecast ability of each individual card once, for a total of however many of those cards you have in your hand."

So if you have 6 White/blue creatures in play, and 3 of these in your hand, you can draw 4 cards at the start of your turn. I suggest casting one, to untap those creatures though. :)

97110: Anthem of Rakdos.author: Japicx
97110: Anthem of Rakdos.text_parsed: This card is one of the key pieces in my Malfegor EDH deck, for obvious reasons. And I honestly don't get why people are so in a dither about the fact that the Anthem doubles the damage it deals to you. Taking 2 damage per attacker is nothing compared with the massive hurt you'll be laying on your opponent. If you're playing a hellbent deck, you should have a few Dread Slags in there. As long as you're hellbent and you have the Anthem and the Slag in play, you've got a five-mana trampler that swings for 22 damage. That swing will do 2 damage to you, for sure, but who cares if your opponent is taking eleven times that much? To me, this is the king of all hellbent cards.

97110: Anthem of Rakdos.text_parsed:
@Superllama12
That combo is nice, but really, you don't need to prevent the damage to yourself. If you are an aggro deck (and you should be if you are going for hellbent), you shouldn't care about the life loss.

This is more like an overrun effect that deals insane damage, but has some drawbacks. If you play it out right though, you can kill people extremely quickly with this - easily on the turn you play it.

Somethings as simple as thatcher revolt could end up doing 18 damage! Ya, sure, you take 6 damage, but who cares?

97110: Anthem of Rakdos.author: RakdosRiot
97110: Anthem of Rakdos.text_parsed: Remember: the Hellbent double damage is in *ADDITION TO* the +2/0! Don't underestimate how big the boost is with Hellbent! This thing turns ALL your creatures--even lowly 1/1s--into heavy hitters when you have no cards in hand. 2x(pow+2) means 1/1s swing for 6, 2/2s for 10, and double strikers get 2x+8 damage. This is a fierce enchantment.

97112: Trygon Predator.author: Donovan_Fabian
97112: Trygon Predator.text_parsed: I like this card but at the same time I feel you can get so much artifact and enchantment removal that you have to want to replace another creature in your deck to use this.  I got aura shards out of a booster pack, and then I compared it with this card, and I realized aura shards is a lot better.  You can get the use of aura shards with tokens, it activates anytime your creature reaches the field rather than damages your opponent, and isn't necessarily quite as easy to get rid of (you can't simply lightning bolt an enchantment for example).  However, if you're playing against esper, or playing a simic heavy deck, it certainly doesn't hurt.

97117: Prahv, Spires of Order.author: Enelysios
97117: Prahv, Spires of Order.text_parsed:
Perfectly usable in EDH. Kor Haven is usually better, but since this doesn't target, it will stop damage from hexproof targets (As generals are often made) and it can stop damage from spells as well.

This was clearly designed for control decks where you spend your mana on your opponent's turn. I think the cost is high enough that I would be reluctant to play it in even a very casual 60 card deck. Still, the art and flavor text are good and its not Nivix, so that's something.

97118: Palliation Accord.author: blurrymadness
97118: Palliation Accord.text_parsed:
Annoyingly big effect against any sort of weenie deck. Teaches new players (among many many other cards) that swarms almost always need a big baddy supporting them somewhere. Favorite in this case would be Saprolings and a Germinator as you still only need X+1 tokens (where X = the number of defenders) and then a boatload of them sitting backline

Still, saving up that many saps can be painful if they're boardwiping, or any number of other problematic over-extending counters. I'm glad that it's 5 mana so it stays out of the game for awhile.

97119: Rakdos Riteknife.author: LiXinjian
97119: Rakdos Riteknife.text_parsed:
Having to tap the equipped creature really kills this card. What, I have to sacrifice a creature to get a measly +1/+0, and on top of that, my equipped creature must not attack or use any of its activated abilities?!?

Another solution would be to pay 2 and equip the knife onto the creature you want to sacrifice. Not the best way to spend your mana, and your turn, unless you have a grave pact on the battlefield. If you could find a viable way to add blood counters without all that sacrificing and tapping, maybe you could do great things with this card. Maybe.

Not the best way to spend your mana, and your turn, unless you have a [autocard]grave pact[/autocard] on the battlefield. 97119: Rakdos Riteknife.author: achilleselbow
97119: Rakdos Riteknife.text_parsed: You don't seem to realize that the sacrifice ability can be activated as an instant, which means you can and should use it to respond to any removal as long as you keep the equipped creature untapped and ready. The counters also stay on the knife regardless of what happens to your creatures, which gives it a plus over things like Blade of the Bloodchief. Insane card advantage once you've gotten a few counters on it.

97119: Rakdos Riteknife.author: Cyberium
97119: Rakdos Riteknife.text_parsed:
A good creature to use this equipment on is a wall. Wall typically is there to block and often has no other ability (and of course, no need of attacking) so tapping isn't an issue. The more counters on the Knife, the more deadly as a blocker it would be, and It can sacrifice itself if it needs to. On the same facet, Reassembling Skeleton can serve equal purpose, or token generator like Rotlung Reanimator.

Given how hefty the cost of this equipment is, I think the cost should be lowered. The reward, however, is huge. Proliferate also reduces the burden.

97119: Rakdos Riteknife.author: Kelptic183
97119: Rakdos Riteknife.text_parsed:
This is actually really easy to use, although it takes time to build up. Sac creatures at instant speed in response to some removal, or sac your chump blockers. The longer they go without killing it, the more dangerous it becomes, and the more they have to kill it. Never sac the knife itself until they try to kill it or if it will win the game. I like that it not only is a time bomb just waiting to go off, it also pumps your creatures in the meantime. A great card in EDH.

Also, It that Betrays and proliferate.

97119: Rakdos Riteknife.author: ScepterofEternities
97119: Rakdos Riteknife.text_parsed:
The rating for this card is currently 3.333... A tad bit eerie, and I don't really want to change this.

That aside, this can be a great card. Throw this in a casual jund deck and it can become quite powerful. Or, for that matter, a goblin deck. You equip it to a sprouting thrinax/token of your choice, tap it to sacrifice it, and pay 2 to equip it to another creature/ one of the tokens you just made, which you sacrifice again. By turn six, you could force your opponent to sacrifice five, possibly six permanents, which is pretty devestating.

Now, if the equip cost one, or you didn't have to tap to sacrifice, or just didn't have to sacrifice, this card would be broken. As it is, it's pretty balanced and a good card.

97119: Rakdos Riteknife.author: Mode
97119: Rakdos Riteknife.text_parsed:
This card is taunting you with potential crippled by mediocrity so hard.
It almost hurts as much to think about it than getting stabbed by it.

I'd like this card if just it was for either one of these seven things:
(1)Tapping the equipped creature to activate the cost,
(2) The equipped creature got +2/+0 for each counter instead,
(3) The equipped creature got +1/+1 for each counter instead,
(4) Using blood counters rather than more comboable charge counters,
(5) The casting cost of ,
(6) The equip cost of , and most of all
(7) The activation cost to sacrifice it.
So many possibilites that would have made this more worthwhile. Argh!
Without (1), this would have been the biggest difference, since you could simply have mass-murdered all your exposable creatures then in one go and immediately wreck your opponent. Which might be why they added . But that makes the +1/+0 boost even less useful, since you'll always want to built up the counters so you can eventually pop it rather than using it for a measly +3/+0. (2) would have made it much more viable, since it would turn into an n-fold Bonesplitter. (3) would have made it much more useful for defense (or repeated attack) with the extra toughness. (4) would have made it grat with cards like Coretapper or Energy Chamber. (5) would have made it faster allowed a lot more interaction with trinket cards like Trinket Mage. (6) would have made equipment change much more viable. would still have prevented "bombing" as described about (1).
And, oh god, (7). If just saccing it would have been instead or even for free, I'd have liked this card so much more. Like that, you always want to keep two mana open to make sure your opponent won't shatter it. Or you have to rely on cards like Intomidable Archangel.

Like this, you have to pay six mana, tap a creature, and sacrifice a creature to make your opponent sacrifice one permanent. And when it's initially equipped, it does absolutely nothing.
In a proliferate deck though, you could also use Throne of Geth for example to add blood counters.

97119: Rakdos Riteknife.author: Mr.Freshness-Timmy
97119: Rakdos Riteknife.text_parsed:
I made a sacrifice themed jund deck with this, savra,lyzolda,jund hackblade, some devour dudes, more hybrid colour dudes and gilder bairn, with a few planeswalkers like sarkhan or garruk for control and fixing.


This goes on gilder bairn, you sac tokens from mycoloth or sprouting thrinax and you use this guy to double the counters on the knife or a planeswalker, repeat if you have the mana, then somebody loses the game and somebody else loses a field.

97120: Vigean Intuition.author: Cyberium
97120: Vigean Intuition.text_parsed:
This card isn't good, but it isn't bad either. It does two things Tiding couldn't:

1) Instant speed compare to Tiding's Sorcery.
2) It put cards into your graveyard. This may not sound useful but if you are relying on putting certain cards into your grave (or threshold requirement) the card does it for you. In a U/G threshold/flashback deck, you can always name 'creature', and dump the rest into your graveyard for flashback.

3/5

97120: Vigean Intuition.author: Lash_of_Dragonbreath
97120: Vigean Intuition.text_parsed:
Hm... Instant speed, puts stuff in your graveyard, GU is the best color combination to know what are the top cards of your library... Still, this isn't the least bit appealing to me, and I'm a big U/G enthusiast.
If you care about the instant-speed card draw, run either Opportunity or Jace's Ingenuity instead.
If you care about sending stuff to your graveyard, run either Fact or Fiction, Truth or Tale, or Tracker's Instincts instead.
